0.paragraph: Address: 1002 St Kilda Road, Melbourne, Victoria
source:
page_content='The  monitoring  of  pre-works  at  the  site  uncovered  a  number  of  archaeological  features  and  the 
methodology  was  changed  from  monitoring  to  excavation.  The  excavation  achieved  its  aim  of 
investigating the nature, location and extent of previously unidentified features in the development 
footprint for the development. Amongst the features uncovered were ephemeral 1850s settlement 
adjacent to St Kilda Road, garden and playground structures from the RVIB, a cottage hospital built on 
the site in the 1880s and a World War II air raid trench. The opportunity to investigate such a range of 
features in inner Melbourne is extremely rare and this project allowed a glimpse into some of St Kilda 
Road’s history, the RVIB’s history and was the first time a WW2 air raid was excavated in Victoria.  

The following report presents the results of the historical excavation.  

Recommendations' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

page_content='The following report presents the results of the historical excavation.  

Recommendations 

Archaeological works conducted under Heritage Permit P12221 have determined the location, nature 
and extent of the historical archaeological material present in the area of investigation. The excavated 
features have been preserved by record and the development has begun on the site.  

The RVIB remains a registered historical place on the VHR. Future management recommendations of 
the site will be determined by Heritage Victoria.  

i 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002 

1 ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS    

Green  Heritage  Compliance  and  Research  would  like  to  sincerely  thank  the  following  people  and 
organisations for their assistance.

Jeremy Smith and Maddi Miller, Heritage Victoria

\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002

Part 2  

Archaeological Investigation  

24 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002 

1 3.  AIMS AND METHODOLOGY      

The  historical  archaeological  investigation  was  carried  out  in  November  and  December  2014.  The 
excavation  director  was  Barry  Green;  the  supervisors  were  Brian  Shanahan  and  Alana  Doyle;  site 
assistants were Elise Landry, Amalia Carrol, and Trudy White.  

3.1 

Aims' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

page_content='64 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002 

1 6.  DISCUSSION     

The  Research  Design’s  goal  was  to  formulate  ways  to  interrogate  the  datasets  generated  by  the 
excavation to better understand pastoral life in a local and regional context  during the nineteenth 
century.  The  investigation  of  this  site  has  the  potential  to  add  to  our  knowledge  of  the  lives  and 
material culture of Victoria’s early European settlers.   

6.1 

Descriptive  

•  What is the archaeological record of the site? 

The archaeological record of the site consists of the 1850s ephemeral settlement, site boundary and 
service features, RVIB playground features, the foundations of the 1880s cottage hospital and a WWII 
air raid trench.  

•  What occupational deposits and subsoil-cut features are present?' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

1.paragraph: Example: The main findings from the archaeological investigation of the RVIB site include evidence of an 1850s ephemeral settlement, a 1880s cottage hospital and nursery, a 1930s playground, and a World War II air raid trench.

1 6.  DISCUSSION     

The  Research  Design’s  goal  was  to  formulate  ways  to  interrogate  the  datasets  generated  by  the 
excavation to better understand pastoral life in a local and regional context  during the nineteenth

6.1 

Descriptive  

•  What is the archaeological record of the site? 

The archaeological record of the site consists of the 1850s ephemeral settlement, site boundary and 
service features, RVIB playground features, the foundations of the 1880s cottage hospital and a WWII 
air raid trench.  

•  What occupational deposits and subsoil-cut features are present?' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

page_content='the site? 

3.1.3 

Interpretive  

•  How do the results of the archaeological investigation correlate with the historical record for 

the site? 

•  How do the results of the archaeological investigation compare with similar excavated sites in 
Victoria and south east Australia in general? If no similar have been previously excavated, how 
does this site inform future excavations about the types of archaeological features likely at 
institutional / education sites? 

•  What does the artefact assemblage tell us of the material culture of the sites occupants and 
users and how does this relate to written accounts of life at the RVIB site corresponding to the 
phases of occupation and use? 

•  How has the archaeological investigation of the site contributed to our broader knowledge of 

the RVIB and institutional life in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries? 

25 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002

3.paragraph: The excavation site is located in Melbourne, specifically within the boundaries of St Kilda Road.
source:

methodology  was  changed  from  monitoring  to  excavation.  The  excavation  achieved  its  aim  of 
investigating the nature, location and extent of previously unidentified features in the development 
footprint for the development. Amongst the features uncovered were ephemeral 1850s settlement

the site in the 1880s and a World War II air raid trench. The opportunity to investigate such a range of

Road’s history, the RVIB’s history and was the first time a WW2 air raid was excavated in Victoria.  

The following report presents the results of the historical excavation.

Part 2

\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002 

1 3.  AIMS AND METHODOLOGY      

The  historical  archaeological  investigation  was  carried  out  in  November  and  December  2014.  The 
excavation  director  was  Barry  Green;  the  supervisors  were  Brian  Shanahan  and  Alana  Doyle;  site 
assistants were Elise Landry, Amalia Carrol, and Trudy White.  

3.1 

Aims' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

page_content='After the purchase of the cottage hospital allotment, ground works were carried out for drainage of 
the entirety of the site and pits were dug for plantings and fencing.  

The  excavation  identified  a  system  of  drainage  ditches,  fence  lines  and  planting  pits.  One  shallow 
drainage ditch C2003, running south north through the centre of the allotment was predominantly 
filled  with  construction  rubble  (bluestone  flakes,  brick  fragments,  metallurgical  waste  etc)  and 
domestic refuse (ceramic, glass and disarticulated bone). Sample excavation of a 2m section of the 
ditch  retrieved  over  2,000  artefacts  including  Victorian  Asylum  and  School  for  the  Blind  branded 
ceramic and a cache of discarded carbon rods used in early electric lighting. The ditch was most likely 
dug and backfilled post-1880s during the RVIB occupation of the site.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5178_Archaeological Investigations at The Royal Vic Institute for the Blind, St Kilda.pdf'}

page_content='The following report presents the results of the historical excavation.  

Recommendations 

Archaeological works conducted under Heritage Permit P12221 have determined the location, nature 
and extent of the historical archaeological material present in the area of investigation. The excavated 
features have been preserved by record and the development has begun on the site.  

The RVIB remains a registered historical place on the VHR. Future management recommendations of 
the site will be determined by Heritage Victoria.  

i 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cRoyal Victorian Institute for the Blind H1002
